text: Our Vision: Be the preeminent banking partner for institutions with cross-border needs, a global leader in wealth management and a valued personal bank in our home market.
Transformation is our #1 priority, involving relentless execution, regulatory remediation, modernizing infrastructure, and data enhancements.
To invest for growth, we will maximize our unique global network, grow the Commercial Banking client sector, scale Wealth, and target share gains in Banking, Markets, and U.S. Personal Banking.
Simplification efforts include focusing on five core interconnected businesses, exiting 14 international consumer markets, and simplifying the organization and management structure.
For Culture and Talent, we aim to build a winning culture, invest in talent, and Deliver One Citi.

2021-2023 Priorities included executing on transformation, developing a refreshed strategy, progressing on divestitures, simplifying organizational structure, establishing a winning culture, and improving business performance.

Priorities for 2024 and beyond are to execute on the transformation and improve business performance, centered around five core businesses: Services, Markets, Banking, Wealth, and U.S. Personal Banking.
In Transformation, we retired 110+ technology applications, built greater efficiency in risk management with 99% of risk computations on cloud infrastructure, and improved system resiliency.
A robust position management tool was launched to better track, manage, and forecast roles across Citi.
We are intensifying efforts in 2024 to accelerate progress in automating regulatory processes and remediating data.
In Strategic Execution, Services momentum continued, driven by client activity and new wins, with Citi Token Services winning an innovation award.
In Markets, the unified Spread Products business benefited from strong activity in financing and intermediation.
Investment Banking is seeing share gains from past investments and industry alignment.
Wealth saw double-digit non-interest revenue growth with a focus on growing investment assets and scaling alternatives.
USPB revenue momentum was driven by robust borrowing, product innovation, and benefits from Simplified Banking.

Progress on divestitures includes the Banamex leadership team announcement (Mexico separation on track for 2H24), wind-downs in Korea, Russia, and China being ahead of plan, and the China Consumer Wealth portfolio sale on track for 2024 completion.
In Organization, Culture, and Talent, we completed organizational changes, including a headcount reduction of ~7,000 in 1Q24 from broader restructuring.
Over 98% of the bank now operates under 8 layers (excluding the CEO).
The average span of control for managers improved by ~2, and we eliminated more than half of internal governance committees.
Announced Vis Raghavan as new Head of Banking and Andrei Magasiner as new Treasurer.
Promoted a diverse global managing director class, with women comprising nearly 30%.
Services: Continued momentum with TTS maintaining a 10.0% market share and Securities Services gaining ~60bps of market share YoY in 2023.
Markets: Strong performance in Spread Products, which were up 26% along with Other Fixed Income. Continued progress in Prime with balances up over 10% YoY.
Banking: Gained share of a recovering IB wallet, with DCM Fees up 62% YoY and ECM Fees up 57% YoY. Seeing good momentum in announced Technology and Healthcare M&A.
Wealth: NIR up 11% YoY on market performance and investment asset focus. Estimated Client investment assets up 12% YoY and Client balances up 6% YoY.
USPB: Continued double-digit revenue growth on flat expenses. Branded Cards and Retail Services revenues up 7% YoY and 18% YoY, respectively.
Returned ~$1.5 billion in capital to common shareholders through dividends and share buybacks.

Revenues decreased (2)% YoY. Excluding divestiture-related impacts of $1 billion, revenues increased more than 3%, driven by growth across Banking, USPB and Services, partially offset by lower revenues in Markets and Wealth.

Expenses were up 7% YoY, including $258 million of repositioning costs, $251 million from the incremental FDIC special assessment, and $225 million of restructuring charges. Excluding divestiture-related impacts and the FDIC assessment, expenses were up 5%.
Credit Costs were $2.4 billion, primarily driven by higher card NCLs. At quarter-end, total reserves were nearly $22 billion with a reserve-to-funded loans ratio of approximately 2.8%.
Net Income was $3.4 billion, as lower non-interest revenue and higher expenses/credit costs more than offset higher net interest income.
In 1Q24, we took an additional $225 million of restructuring charges, largely related to organizational simplification, totaling approximately $1 billion across the last two quarters.
These actions are driving a headcount reduction of ~7,000 and ~$1.5 billion of annualized run rate saves over the medium-term.
In addition to restructuring, we incurred ~$258 million of repositioning costs largely related to efficiency efforts, including the reduction of stranded costs associated with consumer divestitures.
The expected savings from these actions will allow us to continue to fund additional investments in the transformation this year.
The benefits from the restructuring and reduction of stranded costs are expected to result in ~$2-2.5 billion of annualized run rate saves over the medium-term.
FY24 Expense Guidance is $53.5B-$53.8B ex-FDIC special assessment.
Total End-of-Period (EOP) Consumer Loans stood at $382 billion.
Total Corporate Lending Exposure was $706 billion.
The 1Q24 CET1 Capital ratio is 13.5%, driven by strength in earnings and a reduction in RWA.
These positive drivers were largely offset by capital distribution (dividends and repurchases) and a seasonal increase in disallowed DTA.
Citi is well capitalized with a CET1 Capital ratio of 13.5%, which is ~120bps above the current 12.3% regulatory capital requirement.
The current CET1 Capital ratio of 13.5% includes a 100bps management buffer.
Revenues up 8% YoY, driven by continued momentum across both TTS and Securities Services. NII increased 6% and NIR increased 14%.
Expenses up 11% YoY, primarily driven by continued investments in technology and product innovation.
Credit Costs were low at $64 million as net credit losses remain low.
Net Income was approximately $1.5 billion, up 15% YoY.
RoTCE for the Services segment was 24.1%.
Revenues were down (7)% YoY, driven by Fixed Income (down (10)%), partially offset by Equities (up 5%).
The Fixed Income decline was driven by Rates and Currencies, reflecting lower volatility against a strong prior-year quarter, partially offset by strength in Spread Products.
Equities benefited from growth across cash trading and equity derivatives.
Expenses were up 7% YoY, largely driven by the absence of a legal reserve release in the prior year.
Credit Costs were $200 million, primarily driven by changes in macroeconomic assumptions related to loans in Spread Products.
Net Income was approximately $1.4 billion, down (25)% YoY.
RoTCE was 10.4%.
Revenues were up 49% YoY, driven by Investment Banking revenues up 35% (DCM and ECM growth) and Corporate lending (ex-gain/loss on loan hedges) up 34%.
Expenses were down (4)% YoY, primarily driven by actions to right-size the expense base.
Credit Costs were a benefit of $(129) million, primarily driven by changes in portfolio composition.
Net income was $536 million.
RoTCE for the Banking segment was 9.9%.
Revenues down (4)% YoY, driven by lower NII (down (13)%) due to lower deposit spreads and higher mortgage funding costs, partially offset by higher NIR (up 11%).
Expenses up 3% YoY, driven by technology investments, partially offset by initial benefits of actions to right-size the expense base.
Credit Costs showed a benefit of $(170) million, primarily related to a change in estimate as we enhanced our data related to margin lending collateral.
Net Income was $150 million.
RoTCE for the Wealth segment was 4.6%.
Revenues were up 10% YoY, driven by NII growth of 8% and lower partner payments.
Expenses were roughly flat, reflecting lower compensation costs, offset by higher repositioning costs and volume-related expenses.
Credit Costs were $2.2 billion, driven by higher NCLs of $1.9 billion as card loan vintages from the past few years mature.
Net Income was $347 million.
RoTCE for the USPB segment was 5.5%.
Revenues were down (9)% YoY, primarily driven by closed exits and wind-downs, as well as higher funding costs, partially offset by higher revenues in Mexico.
Expenses were up 18% YoY, primarily driven by the incremental FDIC special assessment and restructuring charges, partially offset by lower expenses from both wind-down and exit markets.
Credit Costs of $185 million decreased 59% YoY, largely driven by the absence of a reserve build in the prior year period, partially offset by higher net credit losses in Mexico Consumer.
Full year 2024 revenue guidance is ~$80-81 billion, with NII ex-Markets down modestly YoY.
NIR is expected to be driven by fee growth in Services, a rebound in Investment Banking and improvement in Wealth, and lower partner payments in Retail Services.
Full year 2024 expense guidance is ~$53.5-53.8 billion ex. FDIC special assessment, and includes $700 million to $1 billion of repositioning and restructuring charges.
Full year average NCL rate guidance is 3.50-4.00% for Branded Cards and 5.75-6.25% for Retail Services, with some quarterly variability expected due to seasonality.
Citi will continue to evaluate buybacks on a quarterly basis, having repurchased $500 million in 1Q24.
Medium-term revenue targets include a 4-5% CAGR, capitalizing on a rebound in the Banking wallet and refocusing the Wealth strategy.

Medium-term expense targets include a <60% efficiency ratio ($51-53 billion), with reductions from organizational simplification, market exits, and stranded costs, alongside benefits from transformation investments.
Medium-term credit targets include 6-7% loan growth and 1% Total CoC % Loans as NCLs moderate to normalized levels.
Citi expects capital benefit from exits and simplification over time.
Committed to 11-12% RoTCE Medium-term Target.
Certain statements in this presentation are “forward-looking statements” based on management's current expectations and are subject to uncertainty.

Actual results may differ materially due to various factors, including Citi's ability to achieve objectives from its transformation, impacts from central bank interest rate policies, revisions to U.S. Basel III rules, inflation, and geopolitical uncertainties like the war in Ukraine and conflict in the Middle East.
These factors also include those contained in Citigroup's filings with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission, including the "Risk Factors" section of its 2023 Form 10-K.
Citi does not undertake to update forward-looking statements.
Citi has operated in Argentina for over 100 years, serving approximately 1,300 clients, including 700 multinational clients (MNC).
Primary activities are liquidity management, payments, and custody within Services.
Approximately 80% of total assets consist of cash, reverse repos, and securities. Loans total approximately $572 million, with low credit losses over the last 10 years.

Citi has a cumulative translation adjustment (CTA) loss balance of approximately $2.5 billion, which is capital neutral and only recognizable in earnings upon substantial liquidation or loss of control.
In 2023, Citi's net investment declined $0.7 billion to $1.0 billion, due to a $1.9 billion peso devaluation loss and a $0.5 billion onshore transfer risk reserve build.
In 2024, further peso devaluation is expected, though less significant than in 2023, and these impacts are incorporated in the $80-81 billion revenue guidance.
The net investment increased to $1.6 billion in 1Q24, driven by earnings from increased client activity and NII.
As of March 31, 2024, ~$0.9 billion of Citi's net investment exposure is denominated in local currency and subject to further peso devaluation.
Ended nearly all institutional banking services in Russia as of March 31, 2023, and continues to wind down consumer and local commercial banking businesses.
Russia exposure increased by approximately $0.4 billion from last quarter due to net increases in unremittable corporate dividends.
Of the $7.0 billion exposure as of March 31, ~$5.1 billion (73%) was unremittable corporate dividends.
Net investment in the Russian entity remained unchanged from the prior quarter at $0.2 billion.
Citi has a CTA loss balance of approximately $1.6 billion related to its Russian subsidiary, which is only recognizable in earnings upon liquidation or loss of control (capital neutral).
A loss of control of the entity would trigger recognition of a $0.6 billion loss on intercompany liabilities.
Our available liquidity resources of about $965 billion are comprised of HQLA and other unencumbered securities and unused borrowing capacity.
The average HQLA of $552 billion that we hold exceeds Net Cash Outflow of $473 billion by ~17% or about ~$79 billion, resulting in a 1Q24 LCR of 117%.
Our level of available liquidity resources means we have approximately $492 billion of liquidity above and beyond the stressed outflow assumptions under the LCR requirement.
